Institute of Catalysis for Energy and Environment Shenyang Normal University Shenyang 110034 China ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. 1 Co-first author V-incorporated mesoporous KIT-6 silica materials with different V content (xV-KIT-6) were used for partial oxidation of methane (POM) with dioxygen under atmospheric pressure. Turnover frequency of CH4 (TOFCH4) is basically indistinguishable for highly dispersed VOx species under (sub-)monolayer coverage on SiO2. However, the polymerization degree of VOx species significant affect HCHO selectivity. At 625 °C, 3V-KIT-6 catalyst exhibited best catalytic performance of POM: methane conversion was 8.1%, formaldehyde selectivity was 26.1% and selectivity of the incomplete oxidation products was 90.5%. Compared with 3V-KIT-6 catalyst, the supported 1.1V/KIT-6 catalyst with same vanadium content and dispersity exhibit poor high-temperature TOFHCHO and low-temperature HCHO selectivity, suggesting that the supported and incorporated VOx species possess different coordination environments, such as VO and VOSi bond length and bond angle. To further investigate their microstructure effect on catalytic performance, in situ and operando UV Raman spectroscopy was used to investigate their different redox properties of VOx species. Under the pure CH4 atmosphere, their VOV or VOSi lattice oxygen are more reducible than VO lattice oxygen, suggesting the former are active sites. Supported VOx species are more easily reduced by CH4 than the incorporated ones, the VO lattice oxygen of 3V-KIT-6 catalyst cannot be completely consumed by CH4 after 1h, at least 30% VO bonds maintained. When 5% O2 was cofed, the VO bonds on 3V-KIT-6 and 1.1V/KIT-6 recovered quickly, indicating that the partially reduced VOx species are oxidized by O2 faster than their reduction by CH4. Thus, the activation of CH4 on VOx species should be the rate-determining step. Some unsaturated VOx species are present on 1.1V/KIT-6 easily, those may generate unselective electrophilic oxygen species for overoxidation. Graphical abstract Polymerization degree and reducibility of VOx species on KIT-6 silica affect the reaction path of methane oxidation by O2. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Highly dispersed active sites V doped KIT-6 silica Selective oxidation of methane Formaldehyde In situ UV Raman Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Methane is a promising feedstock in energy and chemical industry [1]. Methane combustion is the main way of utilization with inevitable carbon emissions. Therefore, transforming methane into high-value chemicals has higher environmental and economic value. However, the traditional industrial route of methane to chemicals needs to be carried out at least two steps (indirect conversion) with high investment cost in the early stage and high energy consumption during the reaction processes, which is not a convenient route for methane utilization, especially for the natural gas at remote region [2,3]. Researchers have been devoted to working on direct conversion of CH4 into transportable value-added liquid oxygenates [4–8]. Due to methane extremely stable chemical properties, its activation must supply enough energy or active species/sites, while the target product is often more active than the reactant methane, thus the yield of the target product is relatively low and has not yet been able to meet the requirements of industrialization. Therefore, the direct conversion of methane into oxygenates is one of the most challenging reactions in the field of catalysis [9–12]. VOx based catalyst is considered to be one of the most widely used and effective catalysts in gas-solid heterogeneous catalytic reactions for the POM to CH3OH and HCHO at high temperature [13–16]. Highly dispersed and isolated VOx species are identified as responsible for selective oxidation of methane, while polymerized species are liable to result in the deep oxidation. Therefore, abundant research has focused on how to prepare catalysts with highly dispersed VOx species to limit the active oxygen for abstracting H and inserting O of CH4 molecular [17–19]. However, the metal oxide supports, like TiO2, MgO, γ-Al2O3 and ZrO2, etc. [20–22], are rich in Lewis acid sits. Lewis acidic sites are capable of activating methane through heterolytic splitting of the CH bond, thus resulting in the further uncontrollable oxidation reaction [23]. However, the silica, which is almost free of Lewis acid sites, is the best inert support reported so far for POM reaction [24–26]. After the emergence of M41S series ordered mesoporous materials by Mobil corporation [27], a variety of mesoporous silica (SBA-16, KIT-6, MCM-48 et al.) with large surface area and abundant mesopores are used as ideal supports for dispersing VOx active species [14,17,28-30], and are beneficial for the methanol/formaldehyde kinetic diffusion to avoid further thermodynamics combustion. Catalyst synthesis methods, such as traditional impregnation [17,31], ion-exchange [19,32], grafting [33,34], vapor impregnation [35] and atomic layer deposition [36], etc., are effective post synthesis technique to disperse the active sites on mesoporous silica. However, the above-mentioned methods typically need the complicated operation processes or expensive equipment. Furthermore, the active species tend to enrich on the surface or at the outlet of the channel, and aggregate to clusters or nanoparticles under high temperature, which causes over-oxidation of target products. However, via in situ self-assemble method, the vanadium source was introduced during hydrolysis of tetraethyl silicate around template micelles to form sol–gel, so that the vanadium atoms can disperse uniformly into the sol–gel. Further crystallization and roasting formed abundant highly dispersed and isolated VOx species [37–41]. In addition, the terminal oxygen of VO bond in V/SiO2 catalysts is initially suggested as the reactive oxygen species by the early catalytic data combined with nitric oxide plus ammonia rectangular pulses and XPS characterization [42]. However, Wachs et al. [25,43] found that CH4 alone could not reduce the isolated VOx on silica at 500 ºC by in situ Raman spectra, indicating that CH4 molecular was not activated initially by the terminal VO bond. HCHO selectivity decreased with increasing reducibility of VOx species supported on different oxide supports, suggesting the bridging VO-Support bonds are real sites for the initial activation of CH4 molecular. Al2O3 shell on the V2O5@SiO2 surface provides new surfaces for the generation of VOAl bonds with inhibiting terminal VO bonds according to the Raman characterization results, which significantly enhanced HCHO yield [36]. In addition, the VOAl bonds are also suggested to be responsible for POM of C2H6 to C2H4 [44]. Furthermore, acidic (OH)xV(OSi)3-x species are also proposed as the actual active sites in V/MCM-1 and V/MCM-48 catalysts on account for the improved activity under H2O steam co-existence [17]. Microscopic electron structures of dispersed VOx species can be modulated by adding promoters. The Ga2O3 promoters facilitate the VOx species reduction without decreasing dispersion. Compared to bare VOx/SiO2, HCHO yield of Ga2O3-VOx/SiO2 increased significantly. Combined with other promoter, the CH4 conversion is related to the changed VOx reducibility rather than VOx dispersion [15]. In this work, the three-dimensional cubic interconnected ordered mesoporous KIT-6 silica with high specific surface area was adopted as the support. Through hydrothermal synthesis method with pH adjustment, a series of V-in-situ-incorporated KIT-6 catalysts were firstly applied to the POM reaction. The effect of different V doping content on the mesoporous structure and VOx species dispersity were investigated systematically. On the basis above, we further investigated the effect of VOx species polymerization degree on the POM performance. TOFCH4 values is basically indistinguishable for highly dispersed VOx species under (sub-)monolayer coverage on SiO2. However, the calculated intrinsic HCHO selectivity basically decreases with the increase of polymerization degree of VOx species. For the corresponding supported 1.1V/KIT-6 catalyst, its content and dispersity of VOx species is both similar with those of the doped 3V-KIT-6 catalyst, but they possess different coordination environments, such as VO and VOSi bond length and bond angle, because of different preparation method (incorporation and impregnation). To further determine their microstructure effect on catalytic performance, in situ and operando UV Raman spectra was used to investigate their different redox property of VOx species. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 The effect of V content on the mesoporous structure As shown in Fig. 1a , all catalysts exhibit typical type IV isotherms and type H1 hysteresis loop in the high-pressure zone of 0.5–0.9 (P/P0), belongs to a rapid capillary condensation in the cubic Ia3d mesoporous structure, indicating that the introduction of V species does not destroy the abundant long mesoporous structure with uniform pore size [45]. Compared with the pure KIT-6, the doped xV-KIT-6 catalysts hysteresis loops shift to higher pressure and exhibit larger average pore diameter, but not for the supported 1.1V/KIT-6. These suggest that the vanadium atom (V atomic radius is much larger than Si atomic radius) incorporation into the Si-O framework result in the pore spatial structure expanding [37]. According to the pore size distribution (Fig. 1b), 5V-KIT-6 catalyst with the most V content exhibits obviously widen peak, indicating somewhat mesoporous structure collapse. As shown in Fig. 2 , all sample exhibit two diffraction peaks at 2 θ of 0.98° and 1.12° belong to (211) and (220) reflections, respectively, indicating a cubic mesoporous structure with Ia3d symmetry [32–34]. With vanadium content increasing, the two peaks of V-KIT-6 catalysts shift to lower angle and their intensities became weaker, suggesting that the V atom incorporation into SiO framework of the molecular sieves [37–41] leads to gradually destroying the long-range order structure in some extent. However, the two XRD peaks of the supported 1.1V/KIT-6 catalyst did not shift, indicating VOx species are on surface or inside channels, almost no V species incorporate into SiO framework of silica. TEM images of KIT-6, xV-KIT-6 (x=0.1–5) and 1.1V/KIT-6 catalysts (Fig. 3 ) visually uncover their internal mesoporous structure. All samples exhibit a well-ordered bi-continuous three-dimensional cubic symmetric structure and their pore diameter was about 9 nm, which was consistent to N2 adsorption/desorption analysis results. 2.2 The effect of V content on the structure of VOx species As shown in Fig. 4 , only a broad peak occurred at ∼23°, corresponding to amorphous SiO2. No V2O5 crystalline phase reflection peaks reveals that these VOx species were highly dispersed. The V elemental mapping image of 3V-KIT-6 catalyst exhibited that VOx species are highly dispersed and no VOx nanoclusters with diameter larger than 0.5 nm are formed (Fig. 5 ). The UV–vis DRS technique is typically applied in the study of VOx species local structures. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the absorption peaks at 213 nm and 261 nm corresponded to the isolated tetrahedral vanadium species, and the absorption peaks at 381 and 450 nm are corresponded to oligomeric vanadium species [19,46]. With the vanadium contents increasing, the intensity of absorption peak at 381 nm increased, indicating that more polymerized vanadium oxide species formed. The polymerization degree of VOx species is correlated with the absorption edge energy (Eg) of UV–vis spectra [47]. The Eg is calculated from the intercept of a straight line fitted through the low energy rising in the graph of [F(R∞ )hν]2 vs. hν (Fig. 6b). The Eg value decreases from 4.2 to 2.4 with the vanadium contents increasing. No peak centered at 483 nm is observed on the all catalysts, which can be assigned to “bulk-like” V2O5 crystallites [48], indicating their VOx species are high dispersed. It coincides with the XRD results. Because of VOx species hydration under ambient environments [49], the UV Raman spectroscopy measurements need to be carried out under dehydration conditions. As shown in Fig. 7 , the Raman peaks of KIT-6 occurring at 802 and 970 cm−1 are attributed to the symmetrical Si-O-Si [49–52] and surface Si-OH [52], respectively. For the vanadium incorporated catalysts (xV-KIT-6) and the supported 1.1V/KIT-6 catalyst, the Raman peaks at 1025 and 1060 cm−1 are assigned to the VO bonds of highly dispersed VOx species under (sub-)monolayer coverage on SiO2 [51,53]. The two peak intensity increases gradually with vanadium content increasing. For the xV-KIT-6(x>1) and 1.1V/KIT-6 catalysts, two weak Raman peak at 682 and 917 cm−1 appeared, those belong to the polymerized vanadium oxide species [53]. Although all V-incorporated and supported catalysts exhibited some polymeric VOx species, no crystalline phase V2O5 formed because of no Raman peak at 987 cm−1. The reducibility of V-incorporated and supported catalysts with different VOx species are shown in Fig. 8 . No obvious H2 consumption peak was found on xV-KIT-6 (x<3) because of the too low VOx content. For 3V-KIT-6 sample, a strong H2 consumption peak at around 553 °C can be attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed V5+ to V3+ [54]. For 1.1V/KIT-6 catalyst, the reduction peak shifts to 533 °C, indicating that the VOx species of the supported catalyst were easier to be reduced than that of 3V-KIT-6. It is consistent with the precious report by Wachs et al. [19,54] the VOx species in silica framework is more difficult to reduce than the surface VOx species species highly dispersed on a silica support. For the 5V-KIT-6 catalyst, a shoulder peak occurred at 609 °C attributes to the reduction of VOV lattice oxygen of polymeric VOx species [46]. For the bulk V2O5 sample, a significant H2 consumption peak occurred at 676 °C, which was absent over the V-incorporated and supported catalysts, revealing that their VOx species are highly dispersed. 2.3 Polymerization degree of VOx species over xV-KIT-6 on the POM performance The xV-KIT-6 catalysts with different V content contain both isolated and oligomeric VOx species. Effect of the ratios of the two on the POM activity were investigated to shed light on the possible relationship between the structure and catalytic activity. Different V content of xV-KIT-6 catalysts significantly affects the VOx dispersity and coordination environment. To investigate their structure-activity relationship, their HCHO productivity as a function of V content under kinetic reacting region are shown in Fig. 9 a. The HCHO productivity increases firstly and then decreases with V content, reaches maximum when the V/Si ratio is 1.1%. It may partially attribute to that more isolated and oligmeric VOx species lead to higher HCHO productivity. However, over-polymeric VOx species supply more unselective oxygen species for over-oxidation (Fig. 10 a). As shown in Fig. 9b, The TOFCH4 values are almost constant with the V content increasing (V/Si<1.1), indicating that TOFCH4 are basically not influent by polymerization degree when the VOx species are under (sub-)monolayer coverage on SiO2. It is consistent with Wachs et al.’ work [47,55]. The 5V-KIT-6 catalyst exhibits low TOFCH4 value, suggesting that the formation of nanocluster or multilayer VOx species levels down the V atom utilization according to the UV–vis DRS results. However, TOFHCHO value decreases linearly with V content increasing (Fig. 9b), suggesting that the polymerization degree of VOx species significant affect the HCHO selectivity at the same TOFCH4 values. Fig. 10a shows HCHO selectivity vs CH4 conversion in kinetic regime (low CH4 conversion), we can suitably fit straight line for each xV-KIT-6 catalysts. The intersection of the fitting line and the Y axis is the calculated intrinsic HCHO selectivity of each catalyst. The methane conversion is closer to 0, the lower the concentration of HCHO generate. Therefore, the possibility of formaldehyde further adsorption-reaction can be avoided. This calculated HCHO selectivity is close to the intrinsic HCHO selectivity of the CH4 oxidation reaction on the VOx active sites [56]. Based on the UV–vis DRS characterization (Fig. 6), the polymerization degree of VOx species can be correlated with Eg value. To further investigate the relationship of VOx polymerization degree and HCHO selectivity, the calculated intrinsic HCHO selectivity as function of Eg are shown in the Fig. 10b. The calculated intrinsic HCHO selectivity basically decreases with the increase of Eg, indicating that the lower the polymerization degree of VOx species, the better the HCHO selectivity. 2.4 The VOx species coordination environments on the POM performance According to above characterization (UV–vis DRS and UV Raman), for 3V-KIT-6 and 1.1V/KIT-6, their VOx species exhibit almost same vanadium atomic density (Table S1) and dispersion degree, but different coordination environments, such as VO and VOSi bond length and bond angle, because of different preparation method (incorporation and impregnation). To further investigate their microstructure effect on catalytic performance, their apparent TOF of methane conversion (TOF CH4) and formaldehyde formation (TOFHCHO) as a function of reaction temperature were compared. Initial temperature of a sudden TOFCH4 increase is typically called ignition temperature [57]. The ignition temperature of 3V-KIT-6 catalyst was 25 °C higher than that of 1.1V/KIT-6 catalyst (Fig. 11a). Furthermore, when the reaction temperature was higher than 575 °C, the TOFHCHO difference value between 3V-KIT-6 and 1.1V/KIT-6 catalyst increased with reaction temperature (Fig. 11b). These demonstrated that the VOx active sites with different coordination environments exhibited different CH4 reaction rate and HCHO formation rate under same reaction condition, especially above 600°C. As shown in Fig. S1 and Table S2, the 3V-KIT-6 catalyst exhibits 8.1% methane conversion, 26.1% formaldehyde selectivity and 90.5% selectivity of the incomplete oxidation products, and excellent stability. No obvious deactivation was observed within 24 h. In the kinetic reaction regime, especially for the CH4 conversion below 2%, 3V-KIT-6 catalyst exhibited higher HCHO selectivity and lower COx selectivity than those of 1.1V/KIT-6 catalyst, indicating that the incorporated VOx species supply more selective oxygen species for HCHO formation, while the supported VOx species supply more non-selective oxygen species for over-oxidation (Fig. 12 ). It is necessary to in-depth explore the essential reasons for the significant difference in methane selective oxidation performance of the 3V-KIT-6 and 1.1V/KIT-6 catalysts. This selective oxidation reaction on VOx species typically divided into two crucial processes, one is that the VOx species supply oxygen species for H abstracting and O inserting along with itself reduction. The other one is the oxidation of the reduced VOx species for completing the catalytic cycle. Hence, in-situ and operando UV Raman spectroscopy characterization for VOx species dynamic detection under reduction and oxidation conditions were adopted. As shown in Fig. S2, the operando UV Raman spectra of 3V-KIT-6 and 1.1V/KIT-6 catalysts exhibit almost the same Raman peaks at 1026 and 1062 cm−1 without changing within 1 h under real reaction condition, suggesting that the reduction rate of VOx species with VO bond are much lower than their oxidation rate. Thus, both the VOx species on the two catalysts kept complete oxidation state. As shown in Fig. 13 , above 450 °C, Raman peaks appeared at ∼1392 and ∼1594 cm−1 corresponding to disordered carbon (D) and graphite carbon (G), respectively [46,47]. The coke formation from CH4 needs the C-H bond cleavage, and the formed CHx polymerization, which typically occurred on the unsaturated VOx active sites. The unsaturated VOx active sites come from alkane/H2 reduction along with their bonded lattice oxygen consumption, including VOV/Support or VO [58–60]. However, the intensity of VO stretching vibration at 1025 cm−1 almost didn't weaken for both the two catalysts when the temperature raised to 500 °C. These suggest that the VOSi or VOV lattice oxygen are more reducible than VO. Furthermore, more coke is formed on 1.1V/KIT-6 catalysts than that of 3V-KIT-6 at the same temperature, suggesting more unsaturated VOx species formed by the reduction of CH4 or its derivatives. It is also consistent with the H2-TPR results. Under higher reaction temperature (625 °C) and CH4 concentration (100%) condition, the VO Raman intensities of 3V-KIT-6 and 1.1V/KIT-6 catalysts as function of time were investigated (Fig. 14 ab B→H). We set the VO Raman peak intensity via an oxidation treatment process as V0 (the 100% oxidation degree and 0% reduction degree). Calculated reduction degree of VOx species at CH4 atmosphere is the ratio of the in-situ VO Raman peak intensity value and V0 (Fig. 14c). Interestingly, the VO bonds on 3V-KIT-6 catalyst cannot be completely consumed by CH4 after 1h, at least 30% V=O bonds maintained. While almost no V=O Raman peaks on 1.1V/KIT-6 catalyst was detected after 50 min in situ CH4 reaction. These demonstrated that the supported VOx species are more easily reduced by CH4 than the incorporated ones. Furthermore, the types of coke deposition on 3V-KIT-6 and 1.1V/KIT-6 catalysts differed, their peak area ratio of graphite carbon and disordered carbon (r(G/D)) was 0.6 and 0.8 (Fig. S3), respectively, indicating that the graphite coke was more easily formed on the supported 1.1V/KIT-6 catalyst. When the 5% O2 was introduced into the CH4 reactant gas flow (Fig. 15 I→O), the coke Raman peaks disappeared after 5 min, indicating that low concentration oxygen molecules are enough to inhibit and combust coke. Meanwhile, the VO bonds on 3V-KIT-6 and 1.1V/KIT-6 recovered quickly (oxidation degree reach around 90%), indicating that the partially reduced VOx species are oxidized by O2 faster than their reduction by CH4. Thus, the reaction between CH4 and VOx species should be the rate-determining step. Further under such low O2 concentration reaction condition, the oxidation degree of VOx species on 3V-KIT-6 catalyst gradually increased to 100% with reaction time. However, the oxidation degree of VOx species on 1.1V/KIT-6 catalyst firstly increased, then decreased to 88% at 30 min, suggesting the existence of some unsaturated VOx species form VO bonds consuming. The oxygen molecules chemisorbed on the reduced VOx sites and easily formed unexpected electrophilic oxygen species, typically leading to over-oxidation of CH4 or HCHO [61]. In contrast, the unsaturated incorporated VOx species quickly converted the chemisorbed oxygen molecules into lattice oxygen, the nucleophilic lattice oxygen with moderate oxidability tended to oxidize CH4 selectively. 3 Conclusions In this work, vanadium-incorporated KIT-6 catalysts with high specific surface area and ordered mesoporous structure were successfully prepared by using the hydrothermal synthesis self-assembly method combined with the pH adjustment method. The 3V-KIT-6 catalyst with approximate metal content showed the best methane selective oxidation performance. At 625 °C, the methane conversion reached 8.1%, obtaining 26.1% HCHO selectivity, and 90.5% incomplete-oxidation-product selectivity. For the incorporated 3V-KIT-6 and supported 1.1V/KIT-6 with the same V content, their similar UV–vis DRS and Raman spectra indicate their similar fraction of VOx monomer in the highly dispersed VOx species under (sub-)monolayer coverage on SiO2. The supported 1.1V/KIT-6 catalyst with same vanadium content and dispersity exhibit poor high-temperature TOFHCHO and low-temperature HCHO selectivity, suggesting that the supported and incorporated VOx species possess different coordination environments, such as VO and VOSi bond length and bond angle. In situ and operando UV-Raman spectroscopy was used to further investigate their relationship of microstructure and performance. Under the pure CH4 atmosphere, their VOV or VOSi lattice oxygen are more reducible than VO lattice oxygen, suggesting the former are active sites. Supported VOx species are more easily reduced by CH4 than the incorporated ones, the VO bonds on 3V-KIT-6 catalyst cannot be completely consumed by CH4 after 1 h, at least 30% VO bonds maintained. When 5% O2 was cofed, the VO bonds on 3V-KIT-6 and 1.1V/KIT-6 recovered quickly, indicating that the partially reduced VOx species are oxidized by O2 faster than their reduction by CH4. Thus, the activation of CH4 on VOx species should be the rate-determining step. Some unsaturated VOx species are present on 1.1V/KIT-6 easily, those may generate unselective electrophilic oxygen species for overoxidation. coredata.dc:description: V-incorporated mesoporous KIT-6 silica materials with different V content (xV-KIT-6) were used for partial oxidation of methane (POM) with dioxygen under atmospheric pressure. Turnover frequency of CH4 (TOFCH4) is basically indistinguishable for highly dispersed VOx species under (sub-)monolayer coverage on SiO2. However, the polymerization degree of VOx species significant affect HCHO selectivity. At 625 °C, 3V-KIT-6 catalyst exhibited best catalytic performance of POM: methane conversion was 8.1%, formaldehyde selectivity was 26.1% and selectivity of the incomplete oxidation products was 90.5%. Compared with 3V-KIT-6 catalyst, the supported 1.1V/KIT-6 catalyst with same vanadium content and dispersity exhibit poor high-temperature TOFHCHO and low-temperature HCHO selectivity, suggesting that the supported and incorporated VOx species possess different coordination environments, such as VO and VOSi bond length and bond angle. To further investigate their microstructure effect on catalytic performance, in situ and operando UV Raman spectroscopy was used to investigate their different redox properties of VOx species. Under the pure CH4 atmosphere, their VOV or VOSi lattice oxygen are more reducible than VO lattice oxygen, suggesting the former are active sites. Supported VOx species are more easily reduced by CH4 than the incorporated ones, the VO lattice oxygen of 3V-KIT-6 catalyst cannot be completely consumed by CH4 after 1h, at least 30% VO bonds maintained. When 5% O2 was cofed, the VO bonds on 3V-KIT-6 and 1.1V/KIT-6 recovered quickly, indicating that the partially reduced VOx species are oxidized by O2 faster than their reduction by CH4. Thus, the activation of CH4 on VOx species should be the rate-determining step. Some unsaturated VOx species are present on 1.1V/KIT-6 easily, those may generate unselective electrophilic oxygen species for overoxidation.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of VOx species polymerization degree and coordination environments of V-KIT-6 catalysts on the performance for the selective oxidation of methane
